This theory was proposed by several scholars over the centuries, but one of the most influential proponents was the German philosopher and physicist, Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz (1646-1716).
Leibniz argued that light is not a form of matter that travels from the eye to the object, but rather that light is an extension of the object itself. According to Leibniz, when an object emits light, it is not the eye that "sees" the light, but rather the mind that perceives the light as it is emitted from the object. In other words, the mind perceives the light as it is emitted from the object, rather than the eye detecting light particles that travel to the mind.
Leibniz's emission theory of vision was a response to the prevailing corpuscular theory of vision, which held that light was composed of tiny particles (corpuscles) that traveled from the eye to the object and were detected by the eye. Leibniz argued that this theory was flawed because it could not explain how the mind could perceive the light emitted from an object without the need for any intervening particles. Instead, Leibniz proposed that light is an extension of the object itself, and that the mind perceives this extension directly.
While Leibniz's emission theory of vision was influential in the history of philosophy and physics, it was eventually superseded by other theories, such as the wave theory of light, which posits that light is a wave that travels through space and is detected by the eye.
